Description: Solid-cast small group-figure representing Isis nursing Horus in copper alloy; Isis represented in a seated position; she holds on her knees Horus with the left arm while presenting her left breast with the right hand to her son; she wears the Hathoric crown and a tripartite wig with uraeus in front (damaged); very simplistic and flat rendering; top of horns and lower legs missing; no suspension loop, so unlikely to have an amuletic purpose; corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by World Museum, Liverpool. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Several bronzes representing Isis nursing Horus were discovered in Naukratis. No less than six of them were discovered in the cache of bronzes in a building located in the southern part of the town (on this cache and its content: Petrie 1886, 41-42; Masson 2015). This figure could pertain to this hoard since it was discovered during the first season of excavation at Naukratis. This group-figure belongs to the type G12 in the typology of bronzes by K. Weiss (Weiss 2012, 330-331, 822-833, Pl. 56, see also Nr. 1508 for this specimen). It became truly popular from the Late Period onwards and one of the most depicted themes in bronze statuary (for example: Grenier 2002, 51-58, pl. VIII-X; Goddio and Fabre 2008, 318-9 no. 178-180; Roeder 1956, § 303-314). Isis nursing is also a theme which is popular in other material in Naukratis (Masson forthcoming b). The very flat and crude design featured on this figure is found on other Naukratite bronzes, such as: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.247, 86.251, 86.261, 86.253 and 86.284; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-EA.616; Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,101.c; BM 1885,1101.568 and BM 1885,1101.91.
